Learn two criteria for linear independence.
Understand the relationship between linear independence and pivot columns / free variables.

introduction.p: Sometimes the span of a set of vectors is smaller than you expect from the number of vectors, as in the picture below. This means that (at least) one of the vectors is redundant: it can be removed without affecting the span. In the present section, we formalize this idea in the notion of linear independence.

subsection.title: The Definition of Linear Independence

statement.p: A set of vectors \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is linearly independent if the vector equation x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_kv_k = 0 has only the trivial solution x_1=x_2=\cdots=x_k=0. The set \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is linearly dependent otherwise.

subsection.p: Linear Independencelinear dependence relation Linear Independenceequation of linear dependence Equation of linear dependenceLinear independence Linear dependence relationLinear independence In other words, \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is linearly dependent if there exist numbers x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_k, not all equal to zero, such that x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_kv_k = 0. This is called a linear dependence relation or equation of linear dependence.

bluebox.p: Note that linear dependence and linear independence are notions that apply to a collection of vectors. It does not make sense to say things like this vector is linearly dependent on these other vectors, or this matrix is linearly independent.

example.title: Vector parametric form
example.p: An important observation is that the vectors coming from the parametric vector form of the solution of a matrix equation Ax=0 are linearly independent. In this we saw that the solution set of Ax=0 for A = \mat{1 -1 2; -2 2 -4}? is x = \vec{x_1 x_2 x_3} = x_2\vec{1 1 0} + x_3\vec{-2 0 1}. Let's explain why the vectors (1,1,0) and (-2,0,1) are linearly independent. Suppose that \vec{0 0 0} = x_2\vec{1 1 0} + x_3\vec{-2 0 1} = \vec{x_2-2x_3 x_2 x_3}. Comparing the second and third coordinates, we see that x_2=x_3=0. This reasoning will work in any example, since the entries corresponding to the free variables are all equal to 1 or 0, and are only equal to 1 in one of the vectors. This observation forms part of this .

subsection.p: The above examples lead to the following recipe.

bluebox.title: Recipe: Checking linear independence
bluebox.p: A set of vectors \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is linearly independent if and only if the vector equation x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_kv_k = 0 has only the trivial solution, if and only if the matrix equation Ax=0 has only the trivial solution, where A is the matrix with columns v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k: A = \mat{| |, , |; v_1 v_2 \cdots, v_k; | |, , |}. This is true if and only if A has a pivot position in every column.

Solving the matrix equatiion Ax=0 will either verify that the columns v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k are linearly independent, or will produce a linear dependence relation by substituting any nonzero values for the free variables.

subsection.p: (Recall that Ax=0 has a nontrivial solution if and only if A has a column without a pivot: see this .)
Suppose that A has more columns than rows. Then A cannot have a pivot in every column (it has at most one pivot per row), so its columns are automatically linearly dependent.

bluebox.p: A wide matrix (a matrix with more columns than rows) has linearly dependent columns.

subsection.p: For example, four vectors in \R^3 are automatically linearly dependent. Note that a tall matrix may or may not have linearly independent columns.

ol.li: Two vectors are linearly dependent if and only if they are collinear, i.e., one is a scalar multiple of the other.
Any set containing the zero vector is linearly dependent.
If a subset of \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is linearly dependent, then \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is linearly dependent as well.
If v_1 = cv_2 then v_1-cv_2=0, so \{v_1,v_2\} is linearly dependent. In the other direction, if x_1v_1+x_2v_2=0 with x_1\neq0 (say), then v_1 = -\frac{x_2}{x_1}v_2.
It is easy to produce a linear dependence relation if one vector is the zero vector: for instance, if v_1=0 then 1\cdot v_1 + 0\cdot v_2 + \cdots + 0\cdot v_k = 0.

After reordering, we may suppose that \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_r\} is linearly dependent, with r < p. This means that there is an equation of linear dependence x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_rv_r = 0, with at least one of x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_r nonzero. This is also an equation of linear dependence among \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\}, since we can take the coefficients of v_{r+1},\ldots,v_k to all be zero.

subsection.p: With regard to the first fact, note that the zero vector is a multiple of any vector, so it is collinear with any other vector. Hence facts 1 and 2 are consistent with each other.

subsection.title: Criteria for Linear Independence
subsection.p: In this subsection we give two criteria for a set of vectors to be linearly independent. Keep in mind, however, that the actual is above.

statement.p: A set of vectors \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is linearly dependent if and only if one of the vectors is in the span of the other ones.
Any such vector may be removed without affecting the span.

proof.p: Suppose, for instance, that v_3 is in \Span\{v_1,v_2,v_4\}, so we have an equation like v_3 = 2v_1 - \frac 12v_2 + 6v_4. We can subract v_3 from both sides of the equation to get 0 = 2v_1 - \frac 12v_2 - v_3 + 6v_4. This is a linear dependence relation.

In this case, any linear combination of v_1,v_2,v_3,v_4 is already a linear combination of v_1,v_2,v_4:
x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + x_3v_3 + x_4v_4 &= x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + x_3\left(2v_1-\frac 12v_2 + 6v_4\right) + x_4v_4
&= (x_1+2x_3)v_1 + \left(x_2-\frac 12x_3\right)v_2 + (x_4+6)v_4.
Therefore, \Span\{v_1,v_2,v_3,v_4\} is contained in \Span\{v_1,v_2,v_4\}. Any linear combination of v_1,v_2,v_4 is also a linear combination of v_1,v_2,v_3,v_4 (with the v_3-coefficient equal to zero), so \Span\{v_1,v_2,v_4\} is also contained in \Span\{v_1,v_2,v_3,v_4\}, and thus they are equal.

In the other direction, if we have a linear dependence relation like 0 = 2v_1 - \frac 12v_2 + v_3 - 6v_4, then we can move any nonzero term to the left side of the equation and divide by its coefficient: v_1 = \frac 12\left(\frac 12v_2 - v_3 + 6v_4\right). This shows that v_1 is in \Span\{v_2,v_3,v_4\}.
We leave it to the reader to generalize this proof for any set of vectors.

bluebox.p: In a linearly dependent set \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\}, it is not generally true that any vector v_j is in the span of the others, only that at least one of them is.

subsection.p: For example, the set \bigl\{{1\choose 0},\,{2\choose 0},\,{0\choose 1}\bigr\} is linearly dependent, but {0\choose 1} is not in the span of the other two vectors. Also see this below.
The previous makes precise in what sense a set of linearly dependent vectors is redundant.

statement.p: A set of vectors \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is linearly independent if and only if, for every j, the vector v_j is not in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{j-1}\}.

proof.p:
It is equivalent to show that \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is linearly dependent if and only if v_j is in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{j-1}\} for some j. The if implication is an immediate consequence of the previous . Suppose then that \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is linearly dependent. This means that some v_j is in the span of the others. Choose the largest such j. We claim that this v_j is in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{j-1}\}. If not, then v_j = x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_{j-1}v_{j-1} + x_{j+1}v_{j+1} + \cdots + x_kv_k with not all of x_{j+1},\ldots,x_k equal to zero. Suppose for simplicity that x_k\neq 0. Then we can rearrange:
v_k = -\frac 1{x_k}\bigl( x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_{j-1}v_{j-1} - v_j + x_{j+1}v_{j+1} + \cdots + x_{p-1}v_{p-1} \bigr).
This says that v_k is in the span of \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{p-1}\}, which contradicts our assumption that v_j is the last vector in the span of the others.

subsection.p: We can rephrase this as follows:

bluebox.p: If you make a set of vectors by adding one vector at a time, and if the span got bigger every time you added a vector, then your set is linearly independent.

subsection.title: Linear Dependence and Free Variables
subsection.p: In light of this and this criterion, it is natural to ask which columns of a matrix are redundant, i.e., which we can remove without affecting the column span.

statement.p: Let v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k be vectors in \R^n, and consider the matrix A = \mat{| |, , |; v_1 v_2 \cdots, v_k; | |, , |}. Then we can delete the columns of A without pivots (the columns corresponding to the free variables), without changing \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\}.
The pivot columns are linearly independent, so we cannot delete any more columns without changing the span.

proof.p:
If the matrix is in reduced row echelon form: A = \mat{1 0 2 0; 0 1 3 0; 0 0 0 1} then the column without a pivot is visibly in the span of the pivot columns: \vec{2 3 0} = 2\vec{1 0 0} + 3\vec{0 1 0} + 0\vec{0 0 1}, and the pivot columns are linearly independent:
\vec{0 0 0} = x_1\vec{1 0 0} + x_2\vec{0 1 0} + x_4\vec{0 0 1} = \vec{x_1 x_2 x_4} \implies x_1 = x_2 = x_4 = 0.

subsection.p: Note that it is necessary to row reduce A to find which are its pivot columns. However, the span of the columns of the row reduced matrix is generally not equal to the span of the columns of A: one must use the pivot columns of the original matrix. See for a restatement of the above theorem.

example.p:
The matrix A = \mat[r]{1 2 0 -1; -2 -3 4 5; 2 4 0 -2} has reduced row echelon form \mat[r]{1 0 -8 -7; 0 1 4 3; 0 0 0 0}. Therefore, the first two columns of A are the pivot columns, so we can delete the others without changing the span:
\Span\left\{\vec{1 -2 2},\;\vec{2 -3 4}\right\} = \Span\left\{\vec{1 -2 2},\;\vec{2 -3 4},\;\vec{0 4 0},\;\vec{-1 5 -2}\right\}.
Moreover, the first two columns are linearly independent.

bluebox.title: Pivot Columns and Dimension
bluebox.p:
Let d be the number of pivot columns in the matrix A = \mat{| |, , |; v_1 v_2 \cdots, v_k; | |, , |}.
If d=1 then \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is a line.
If d=2 then \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is a plane.
If d=3 then \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is a 3-space.
Et cetera.
The number d is called the dimension. We discussed this notion in this and this . We will define this concept rigorously in .
